rev.diff:
Line 107: Line 107:
While Google is the #1 search engine, the company struggles to keep up with rivals such as the well known Yahoo. Although Google and Yahoo differ greatly in the services they offer, Google is trying to redefine itself from an internet search company to an internet media company, similar to Yahoo. Google is trying to become a jack of all trades for the internet. They are foraying into other businesses which other companies have recently dominated. On June 21st 2005 Google announced it has plans to release a pay service and a classified ads service, to rival companies like Ebay [http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/06/20/business/google.php].
While Google is the #1 search engine, the company struggles to keep up with rivals such as the well known Yahoo. Although Google and Yahoo differ greatly in the services they offer, Google is trying to redefine itself from an internet search company to an internet media company, similar to Yahoo. Google is trying to become a jack of all trades for the internet. They are foraying into other businesses which other companies have recently dominated. On June 21st 2005 Google announced it has plans to release a pay service and a classified ads service, to rival companies like Ebay [http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/06/20/business/google.php].
â
'''==Salaries==
+
==Salaries==
[[Image:Googler2-non.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Googleplex parking lot]]
[[Image:Googler2-non.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Googleplex parking lot]]
Prior to the IPO offering, typical salaries at Google were considered within the industry to be quite low. For instance, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than $33,000– while $37,000 at that time was considered to be low by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] employment market levels. Nevertheless, Google's excellent stock performance following the IPO has enabled these early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth. In 2005 Google has implemented other employee incentives such as the [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C1EFC395F0C728CDDAB0894DD404482 Founder's award], as well making higher salary offers to new employees.
Prior to the IPO offering, typical salaries at Google were considered within the industry to be quite low. For instance, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than $33,000– while $37,000 at that time was considered to be low by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] employment market levels. Nevertheless, Google's excellent stock performance following the IPO has enabled these early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth. In 2005 Google has implemented other employee incentives such as the [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C1EFC395F0C728CDDAB0894DD404482 Founder's award], as well making higher salary offers to new employees.
â
Beyond monetary compensation, Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, stellar prospects (relative to most Bay Area companies), and strong brand recognition continues to attract far more applicants than there are positions available. (It is estimated that less than one job offer is made per thousand resumes submitted.) Google reportedly employs one in-house legal recruiter just to assist the legal department in evaluating the high volume of resumes from attorneys seeking to join the corporation.''' ''' Baleted'''
+
Beyond monetary compensation, Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, stellar prospects (relative to most Bay Area companies), and strong brand recognition continues to attract far more applicants than there are positions available. (It is estimated that less than one job offer is made per thousand resumes submitted.) Google reportedly employs one in-house legal recruiter just to assist the legal department in evaluating the high volume of resumes from attorneys seeking to join the corporation.
==Management==
==Management==
Line 209: Line 209:
*October 2005: Google and [[Sun Microsystems]] join forces to offer online word processing and spreadsheet functions. The partnership will help promote Sun's [[OpenOffice]], [[Solaris Operating Environment|Solaris OS]] and [[Java platform]]; which in turn will assist Google to compete with Microsoft's current dominance in the [[Microsoft Office|Office]] and [[Operating System]] software areas. Google will also purchase hardware from Sun.
*October 2005: Google and [[Sun Microsystems]] join forces to offer online word processing and spreadsheet functions. The partnership will help promote Sun's [[OpenOffice]], [[Solaris Operating Environment|Solaris OS]] and [[Java platform]]; which in turn will assist Google to compete with Microsoft's current dominance in the [[Microsoft Office|Office]] and [[Operating System]] software areas. Google will also purchase hardware from Sun.
â

'''==Major News stories surrounding Google post September 2005==
  â   â   â
Google raised $4 billion in follow-on stock offering, which led to many speculations regarding what the search engine company planned to do with the newly raised cash. Google already had $7 billion in cash prior to the stock offering making a total cash reserve of $11 billion.
  â   â   â
In late September, Google began providing free [[Wi-Fi]] access around areas in the city of San Francisco. It then announced itself to be one of twelve bidders in the city's mayor's invitation to companies, to bid for a plan to offer free Wi-Fi in [[San Francisco]]. Google filed 40 minutes before the deadline. Speculators however do not feel that providing the service around other cities of USA is currently on Google's agenda.
  â   â   â
On Sept 28 Google announced a partnership with [[NASA]] which would involve Google building an R&D center at NASA's Ames Research Center. As reported by SearchEnginejournal.com, NASA and Google were said to be planning to work together on a variety of areas, including large-scale data management, massively distributed computing, bio-info-nano convergence, and encouragement of the entrepreneurial space industry. The new building would also include labs, offices, and housing for Google engineers.
  â   â
In Mid-October Google announced plans to open a large "Googleplex" in Arizona.
  â   â
'''Bold text'''GOOGLE WILL RULE THE WORLD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
  â   â
'''GOOGLE WILL RULE THE WORLD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!'''
  â   â   â
  â
Newb: OMG, I wanna use a search engine. I'll try Yahoo.
  â
Pro: Dude, don't be a newb. Use GOOGLE!
  â
Newb: Wow, thanks I almost lost at the interweb.
 
==Criticism and controversy==
==Criticism and controversy==
Despite Google's apparent success it has also managed to become the target of critics.
Despite Google's apparent success it has also managed to become the target of critics.
